'A while ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are telling everyone, even people you don’t know. This made people think that sharing everything online might not be a good idea. The internet lets us share our lives with many people, which can be exciting. We share stories, photos, and more. But sometimes, we realize it can be risky. 
In the early days of the internet, some people learned these lessons first. They shared their lives online and faced problems like losing jobs or friends. These people were called bloggers. One of the first bloggers was Justin Hall. In 1994, he started sharing his life online. He wrote about everything, and many people read his stories. But one day, he had to stop because it caused problems in his personal life. 
Another blogger, Heather Armstrong, wrote about her job. Someone at her work saw it and told her bosses. She lost her job but later started writing about her family. Now, she is a successful 'mommy blogger' and earns money from her writing. 
The lesson is: the internet lets us say anything, but we should be careful about what we share.'

'Some scientists wanted to warn people about a film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we do not understand. Some scientists were not happy with the film. They said it was bad and even dangerous. 
At first, the film seemed normal. Scientists talked about how new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then, the film talked about water molecules changing because of thoughts. It showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after happy thoughts and not nice after bad thoughts. Some people found this interesting, but many scientists did not believe it. They wanted real proof, not just pictures.
The film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is pushed by a force called 'dark energy'. Other discoveries are also amazing. For example, our brains edit our perception of time, and scientists have found where modern humans came from.
Science is not finished. We are still learning new things. Some scientists are trying to create a Theory of Everything to explain all forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is incredible.'

'Writing novels is hard for me, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important to me. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves. In the garden, flowers bloom, and bees and butterflies come. I like to write both novels and short stories. After I finish a novel, I want to write short stories. After I finish short stories, I want to write a novel. I never write both at the same time. I started writing short stories in 1984. It was difficult at first, but I enjoyed it. My first short story was 'Breaking Waves'. It was in my first short-story book, 'Tales from Abroad'. Short stories are quick to write. It takes me about a week to finish one. Novels take a year or two. Short stories can come from small ideas, like a word or an image. If a short story doesn't work, it's okay. Not every story is perfect. I learn from my mistakes. Short stories help me write better novels. They are like small experiments. My short stories are special to me. They show my feelings, and I like to share them with my readers.'

'Science is very important. It helps us understand the world and can cure diseases. Science makes life easier but can also be dangerous. It tries to understand small things like ants and big things like the universe. Science changes a lot. New ideas often replace old ones. Scientists sometimes disagree, but this helps science grow. 
In the past, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Now, we know more. Scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein helped us understand more about the world. Science is always learning new things. 
Science is not just for scientists. It affects everyone. It can change how we live and the world around us. We need to know about science to make good choices for the future. Science helps us control nature, but we must be careful. It is important for everyone to understand science because it can change our lives and the world.'

'Around 2015, big book companies saw that ebook sales stopped growing or went down. This made people question if ebooks would be important in the future. One person in the book business said that ebooks made his company forget how good paper books are. Even though digital and print books can both be in the market, people still ask if ebooks will replace print books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. Why do we think ebooks and print books are fighting? This is not just about ebooks. It shows how we feel about new things. In the past, people thought new things would end old things. When TV came, people thought radio would end, but radio found new ways to be useful. The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. Many times, people thought new things like movies, radio, and smartphones would end print books. Some people thought this would be bad for culture, while others thought ebooks were great. We often think about the end of books when new technology comes. This shows our hopes and fears about new things. We feel close to things like books and TVs. When new technology comes, we have to change how we feel about these things. This is why we sometimes miss old things. For example, when the printing press came, people wanted old handwritten books. When movies got sound, people missed silent movies. The same happened with photos and music. E-readers made people like old books more, even their smell. This should make people less worried about print books going away. But the idea of things disappearing will always be interesting. It shows how we feel about change and losing things we love.'

'Every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how famous people from the past 400 years did their best work. I wanted to know how they found time each day to be creative and productive. I wrote about their daily lives – when they slept, ate, and worked. I hoped to show a new side of their personalities and careers. This book is about how people work, not what they create. It is also personal. I ask questions like: How do you do creative work and earn money? Is it better to work on a project all at once or a little each day? When there is not enough time, do you give up things like sleep or learn to do more in less time? I do not have all the answers, but I give examples of how successful people faced these challenges. The book is called Daily Rituals, but it is really about routines. A routine can help you use your time, willpower, and optimism well. The psychologist William James said good habits can free our minds. Ironically, he was a procrastinator and could not stick to a schedule. I started this book because I was procrastinating. One day, I was at work trying to write a story, but I was wasting time. I am a morning person, focused in the morning but not after lunch. To feel better, I looked up other writers’ schedules online. I found them interesting and thought someone should collect these stories. So, I started a blog called Daily Routines and then wrote this book. The blog was simple; I posted about people’s routines from biographies and articles. For the book, I collected more stories and let people speak for themselves through quotes. I used many sources, and I listed them in the Notes section for more reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father said they could not go on holiday to Spain because it was too expensive. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found a fossil called an ammonite* on the beach. He decided he wanted to be a palaeontologist. At university, he learned more about what kind of palaeontologist he wanted to be. He was interested in very old fossils, not dinosaurs. He studied small creatures in rocks.
After finishing his studies, Howard worried about getting a job. He knew he was good, but getting a job was not easy. He applied for a job at Tavistock College in London. On the day of his interview, the professor who liked another candidate could not come. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he later learned why he got it.
Howard liked his job, but sometimes things did not go as planned. One day, someone stole his briefcase with his lecture notes. He had to cancel his lecture. While having coffee, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils there. This was a big opportunity for him. He changed his plans to go to Nairobi instead of a conference in Stockholm or a trip to Scotland.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. The larvae look like maggots but taste a bit nutty and floral. Spence and his team study how our senses work together to create the taste of food. This research helps change what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. 
Spence's book, "The Perfect Meal," has many interesting facts about eating. Did you know the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat 35% more with one other person and 75% more with three others? 
Spence's lab in Oxford is simple, with soundproof booths and old equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with chefs who can't pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a big food company. He helps brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. They do it slowly so people don't notice the change. 
Spence met famous chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea" at Blumenthal's restaurant. Spence found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon match music with food for passengers. 
At home, Spence has fun with food experiments. Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used colored lights and sound to see how it changed the taste of drinks. For Spence, home and work are closely connected.

'Our brains are very busy today. We have a lot of information, some true and some not, and we must decide what is important. We also do more things ourselves now. In the past, travel agents booked flights for us, and salespeople helped us in shops. Now, we do these things on our own. We try to do many things at once, like work, family, hobbies, and watching TV. Smartphones help us do this. But there is a problem. We think we can do many things at the same time, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a scientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. We switch quickly from one thing to another, and this is not good for us. It makes us less efficient. Multitasking can make us stressed and confused. Our brains like new things, so we get distracted easily. Just having the chance to multitask can make us perform worse. Glenn Wilson, a professor, says that trying to focus while having unread emails can lower our IQ. Russ Poldrack, a scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. If students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part of the brain that helps us remember better. Making decisions while multitasking is also hard for our brains. Even small decisions use a lot of brain power. We can end up making bad decisions. Many people say email is a big problem because there is too much of it. A scientist's son said his dad just answers emails all day, and the scientist agreed. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do this and do other things too.'

'In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think these questions were important. Scientists studied animal actions and results, but not their feelings. But now, some scientists are starting to study animal emotions. Books like "Wild Justice" and "Do Fish Feel Pain?" talk about this. There is a big question: do animals have feelings like humans? Another question is: do animals know right from wrong? In one study, cows opened a gate to get food. The cows that opened the gate themselves were happier than those that needed help. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? Some people, like Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, think we should stop eating meat. He says this is a big change, like when slavery ended. Professor Aubrey Manning thinks we should think again about how smart animals are. He says animals have a simpler mind than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail says we should not think animals are like humans. These ideas are hard to agree on because they are not just about science, but also about philosophy. It is hard to know what it is like to be an animal. Dr. Balcombe did a study with birds called starlings. Some birds lived in nice cages, others in bad cages. When given bad food, only the birds in nice cages ate it. Dr. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt sad. He believes we will one day see animals like we see people, with rights. Professor Manning agrees that we are changing how we think about animals. He says it is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.'

'Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or listen to. Adrian West, a research director, says that technology helps us store information but can also change how we think. We see a lot of information, but it can be hard to think clearly. More data does not always mean more knowledge. Reading books has gone down, and some people think this affects critical thinking. Patricia Greenfield, a professor, says that focusing on visual media like TV and video games can make us less good at thinking deeply. Technology affects how we think, but we do not know exactly how. Some video games can help us learn and think better. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and thinking skills. In the digital age, it is important to understand how technology affects our thinking.'

Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic. Before this, he worked in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about how working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how hard it is to focus today. He noticed this when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford thinks these ads make it hard for us to think and remember things. We often avoid talking to people because we are tired of interruptions. We use phones and games a lot, which can take over our attention.
Crawford is not alone in worrying about this. Many people feel distracted by emails and phones. Even if a phone is just on the table, it can make us lose focus. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Crawford believes technology makes us focus too much on ourselves. We prefer texting to talking because it feels safer. This can make us lose real connections with people.
Crawford gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone, which sometimes caused disagreements. Now, people use earphones and listen to their own music, making the gym less social. He thinks real connections happen when people work through differences together.
Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public. Second, we should do activities that make us focus on real things, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us use our judgment and connect with the world. They make distractions less powerful. It is important to find ways to focus on what matters.

"‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. I am a philosopher, so it is a bit hard to answer. Saying 'I am a philosopher' can sound strange. People might think philosophers know special truths. This is not true. Philosophers are like everyone else. 
Why do people think philosophers are different? One reason is that philosophers think a lot about life. A Greek philosopher, Aristotle, said thinking about life is very good. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said we should think about our lives. This helps us make good choices. But you do not need to read many books to think about life. You just need to look at your daily life and see what is important.
Philosophy is sometimes seen as far from real life. This is because philosophers often write for other experts. They do not always share their ideas with everyone. This makes philosophy seem hard to understand. 
I work in ethics, a part of philosophy about right and wrong. People often think ethics is about rules and laws. But it is more than that. For example, we can talk about if downloading movies illegally is wrong. Then, we can think about responsibility and art. Philosophy helps us look closely at our actions and beliefs. This is good for everyone."

'People who love food think about what and how we eat. In history, talking about food was often about other things, like learning. Sometimes, people talk about food, but they mean something else. Epicurus, a Greek philosopher, talked about pleasure and avoiding pain. Today, his name is linked to enjoying food and drink. We see his name in restaurants and food shops. Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and we share it with others. We eat with friends and family. Food is important, so people talk and write about it. Some people are good at describing food tastes. We often talk about how things look or sound, but not how food tastes. Some say food should be part of art, like music or painting. But food is eaten, so it does not last like a painting or a song. There are questions about what we should eat, like organic or vegetarian. These choices show our beliefs. Cooking at home is different from cooking in restaurants. At home, we cook for love and friendship. In restaurants, cooks work for their boss and the food. Food can help people from different cultures come together. We can learn about others by eating their food. Eating together helps us make friends from other cultures. This is important in international meetings. A recent essay talks about how food can connect people with fun stories and examples.'

'Rob Daviau is from the US. He makes special board games called ‘legacy’ games. When he was a child, he played many board games. But he thought they were not fun or hard enough. So, he wanted to change them. He asked, "Can board games have a story? Can choices in one game affect the next game?" He changed a board game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices change the game forever. Players might tear cards, write on the board, or open packets with new rules. The game is played over many sessions, and players remember past actions. Daviau also worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a game where players stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall. Pandemic Legacy was very popular, but SeaFall was a big test because it was a new game. In SeaFall, players are sailors exploring new lands. Making legacy games is hard. Designers must think about all player choices. They use testers to see how the game works. Jaime Barriga tested SeaFall. He said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first, but later it breaks, and they must fix it. People did not think legacy games would be very popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved them. He thinks they are exciting and new. Ben Hogg, another fan, likes the adventure in legacy games. He says it is like watching a new movie. Legacy games are like video games and TV shows with episodes. Daviau wanted to write for TV but became a game designer. He likes telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock says making a legacy game is like writing a book. You need to know the start and end. Daviau is happy to see others use his idea. But he thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who works with SeaFall, thinks legacy games change how we see board games.'

'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People like stories about animals escaping, like rats and llamas, because it makes us think animals are like us. Octopuses are very smart. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells as armor. Some people think it is not scientific to say animals are like humans. But Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas, says it is wrong to ignore the human-like traits of animals. He calls this 'anthropodenial.' Animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like think about the past and future, show empathy, and understand others' motives. In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval times, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. In the 20th century, people started to see animals as machines that respond to rewards and punishments. But now, we are learning more about animal intelligence. Dr. de Waal says we should test animals based on their own skills. For example, squirrels are good at remembering where they hide nuts. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested humans, it might think we are not smart because we cannot change our skin color. Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean. But he knows that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He did an experiment with monkeys to show they can feel envy. Monkeys given cucumbers got upset when others got grapes, which they liked more. A video of this experiment convinced many people. This shows how our minds work.'

'Robots were once only in stories, but now they are real and changing the world. Robots have been used in car factories for many years. Now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more places. Many people think robots will do most jobs in 50 years, but they also think their own jobs are safe. This is not true. All jobs will change because of robots. For example, an Australian company made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. In San Francisco, a robot named Tally helps in supermarkets by checking if goods are on the shelves. Robots cannot fix or program themselves yet, so new jobs will be for people who can do this. But some people worry that robots will take away jobs that need people skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang studies how robots change work. He says that soon, robots will work better with people. In a few years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer. Salaries in robotics will go up, but there will not be enough skilled workers. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills because they cannot do the same job forever. New robots will also be in our homes and will be more like people. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs changing, education is important to prepare for the future. We need more people to study science, technology, engineering, and maths, or STEM, to stay competitive.'

George Mallory, a famous climber, was asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He said, "Because it's there." People often wonder why anyone would do something so dangerous. Some think climbing is about adventure and fun. 
In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores wrote about different types of climbing. He said there are seven kinds of climbing, each with its own rules. Over time, this idea became popular in the climbing world.
Many climbers love the feeling of freedom when they climb. But sometimes, climbing can feel limiting, like when stuck in a tent during a storm. This is a bit of a puzzle, but some say the simple life of a climber is a kind of freedom.
Joe Fitschen, a US climber, thinks we should ask, "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our nature. We like challenges, even if they are risky.
Brian Treanor, a US academic, says climbing can teach us important things like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these are important in today's world.
Some climbers, like Ebert and Robinson, believe climbing without help is more special. They think it deserves more praise because it is harder and riskier.
Climbing can also be like meditation. It helps people focus and find peace, similar to Zen philosophy. This is another reason why people might love climbing.

'For over 60 years, Alfred Brendel was a very important pianist in classical music. He was a serious man who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he was serious in concerts. He worked hard, always studying, traveling, and performing. 
Then, a few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not think about teaching him. He had few students before and did not plan to start now. He said, ‘You don’t need a mountain guide to teach a child to walk.’ But something about Kit, who was 14 then, made Brendel listen to him play. Kit played very well and from memory. He gave Brendel a CD of a concert he did, and Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit’s playing was special and rare.
Now, as Brendel is retiring, Kit is becoming known. Brendel is careful, worried Kit might get tired too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy. He learns new languages, studies math, writes computer code, and plays tennis. His mother is always with him. Kit also writes music. Brendel says this is important. Writing music helps you read music better. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. He listens to his own playing and to Brendel’s advice. He understands and can do what Brendel suggests.
Brendel is careful not to raise expectations. He does not like when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century. It is not good to say that. Kit plays some things very well, but he needs more time and experience for others. Critics should not expect perfection.
At 80 years old, Brendel is relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I did not want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by 50. When I was 50, I did most of them, but I wanted to do more, so I continued. Now, I do not have the strength to play, but I still think about music. I don’t play now, but it’s a nice new life.’'

'When I was little, I thought gardens were special places. My grandad's garden was by a river, not in a city. You could hear the water and birds. I thought all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse, but some neighbors did. They made them from old windows.
At home, my dad was quiet. He liked funny things and had special phrases. He left school without finishing and became a plumber. He didn't love plumbing. He and my mom once thought about moving to Canada, but they didn't. My dad was good at fixing things at home, like making bookshelves.
My parents moved house only once. My mom liked to change furniture. One day, we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. It had two brass candlesticks, but my mom took them away. My sister got piano lessons, not me. My mom said I wouldn't have practiced.
I liked going to the river. I would take a fishing net and look for fish. I tried to keep them at home, but it didn't work, so I put them back in the river.
I wanted to leave school early. One day, my dad said there was a job for an apprentice gardener. He thought I might like it. My dad didn't like gardening, but he saw I did. I think he hoped it would be good for me.'

Lawrence MacEwen is on his island, the Isle of Muck, in Scotland. The wind is very strong, but he feels at home. His sheepdog, Tie, is with him. Lawrence shows me the islands around us. He points and says, "That island is Eigg. The one next to it is the Isle of Rum. It rains more there than here." I see rain on Rum's mountains. "Beyond Rum is the island of Soay," he adds.
Lawrence has to move his sheep, so we walk down the hill. He tells me about the island. Muck is three kilometers long and half as wide. The geese eat a lot of grass. The MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. As we move the sheep, Tie, the dog, makes a mistake. Lawrence says, "Away to me, Tie," but Tie doesn't listen. Lawrence is not happy.
The Isle of Muck is run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son, Colin, takes care of the cottages. Their daughter, Mary, and her husband, Toby, run the island hotel. Mary and Toby like that their children can play freely on the island.
Life on the island has challenges. Electricity is not always on. My first night, I wait for the lights. In the morning, Mary makes breakfast with a torch. There is no mobile phone service, but you can get it on the hill. Most people stop using their phones after a few days.
The boat brings groceries and musicians to the island. They play music in the tearoom, and everyone enjoys it. That night, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. Her father bought a farm on the Isle of Soay without seeing it. Jenny went to manage it, even though she only had typing skills.
It rains a lot, but the food is good. Mary sends me to get fresh fish from Sandy Mathers. We eat the fish for dinner, and it is very tasty. The next morning, I wait for the ferry to leave the island. Many ferries were canceled before because of high seas. If my ferry doesn't come, I will stay on Muck for two more days, which I secretly hope for.

'The video game industry used to be small, with only computer scientists and self-taught people. People thought it was just a hobby for young people. Now, the video game industry is important. It is not easy to work in this industry. Making video games needs many people and a lot of time. It is hard to start, but the industry is growing. Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says it is hard to work in big companies. But the industry needs more game designers. Not just the big bosses, but also people who make small parts of games. How can you work in this industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim says you need to make games. You need to show your work. Game design is not just a job, it is a way of life. Another expert, John Field, says it is not easy. Many people want to work in games, but not many have the skills. You need to be creative and know a lot about technology. Can you do it alone? Maybe, but it is hard. A good course in games can help. Most game designers start as programmers or artists. They like all kinds of entertainment and art. They know games are their future. They are not just fans, they are interested in what games can do. Connections are important too. You need to know people to get ahead. The idea of games being just for kids is old. Now, games are for everyone. Families play together. Phones have many games. John thinks there is a lot of room to grow. Games are for big audiences and can teach us things. There are many opportunities in games.'

'When I was a child, I always wanted to play football. My dad helped me, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very strict. He told my friend, 'You can't do this, you can't do that.' My friend stopped playing football because of this. I am happy my dad was not like that. When I score a goal from far away, people say it's luck, but it's not. I practiced a lot since I was a kid. The best players practice for many years. Sometimes young players bump into each other, but I learned good skills. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning. At school, I played many sports like baseball and basketball. I know school is important, but I only thought about football then. I don't want my son to be like that. We read him books, but he likes to kick them. At the start of my football career, the manager helped young players like me. He didn't make a big deal about it. I scored in the first game, but we lost. A TV presenter said, 'You can't win with kids.' That made us work harder. I trust my family and friends a lot. Having a lot of money can be a problem. People say, 'Why does your mom still work?' I help my parents with money. I paid their house loan and bought them a car. My mom loves her job as a hairdresser. I like to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off. I want to go skiing, but I can't now because if I get hurt, I can't play football anymore.'

'We were living at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my dad’s agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn’t write in Los Angeles, so Sam found us a cheap place to live. Reef Point was quiet in the summer because of sea fogs. People didn’t visit much. The road was not nice, and La Carmella, a nicer place, was close by. Only people with no money or who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people came. After months alone, we were now surrounded by people. My dad was busy writing a script and didn’t notice me much. I went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We didn’t have a dog at first, but Rusty came to us. I gave him water, and he stayed. My dad said, ‘He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and brought me things he found. Sometimes, he brought things that weren’t his, like a sneaker or towel, and I returned them. Rusty liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. We swam that day. My dad went to Los Angeles to give his script. Rusty and I watched surfers. One surfer was very good. She came over and asked why I didn’t surf. I said I had no board or money. She asked if I was British and visiting. I said I lived here. She asked about my dad. I said he wrote a book called Tall as the Morning. She knew it and was interested in me after that.'

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship, Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late, but this was bad advice. An announcement said there was a problem with the computer system. People were upset because they paid a lot for the trip. Violet wanted to leave. She looked for her phone in her bag, but it was not there. She needed the phone to call the taxi company. Her son Harry always told her to be careful with her phone. She asked a couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message to ask Kristina, her neighbor, to check if the phone was at home. If it was not there, she would have trouble finding numbers she needed in New York. Violet thought, "Thank goodness," but did not tell Harry. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother. Her other son, Daniel, was more like her and might forget to tell Kristina. Finally, the line moved, and Violet gave her travel papers to go on the ship. She did not like the ship's foyer. It looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were shiny fake wood panels, big chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. Violet went to the elevators, which had mirrors everywhere. The passengers looked tired and did not want to see themselves. Violet was squeezed in the elevator until she got out on the twelfth floor. Her room had the balcony she wanted. She was ready to complain if it did not. She paid a lot to make sure she could see the sea.

'John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction. He did not know he was finding the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about Portage Park in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 pictures by Maier, a street photographer. Maloof now has many of Maier’s things: her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, 100,000 negatives, and many movies and tapes. Maloof feels lucky. He said, ‘When I bought this, I did not know what it was.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and lived in France as a child. In 1951, she went back to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was private and always had a camera. She wore big coats, hats, and strong shoes. Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier, said, ‘On her day off, she had her camera and came back late at night. She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theatre and movies. She was not very social but talked to people on the street and recorded them. She loved taking pictures of the world. Rydzon said, ‘She was a true artist and did what she wanted.’ Maier’s work was pure art, not for money. Her pictures often showed women, children, old people, and the poor. Photography expert Larry Silverman said, ‘Vivian’s pictures are interesting. Did she make her own style or copy others?’ Maloof wonders if he will see all the negatives. He did not like photography before Maier’s work. Her pictures inspired him to take his own. He said, ‘Her work is about people and street scenes. It is more important than I thought. We want people to know Vivian Maier’s name and put her in history books.'

'When a book is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her book. The officer asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for a writer. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are many crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story is very complex. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical book, but found the past gave more chances for problems for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good part. When I ask how it feels to be successful at a young age, she says it is nice because people in her small country feel proud. She says, ‘I got a lot of back pats from other people’s grandmas.’ She adds that it is annoying when people think her book is not serious. She wanted to write the book like a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. It gets faster as it goes. I ask if it matters if readers notice this. She says, ‘I wanted to make a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could see them.’ Even with its special structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery. She says she didn’t plan the book before writing. ‘I would write myself into a corner, then see how I could get out.’ She also wanted the book to be fun for readers. We talk about her love of TV drama series. I ask if she wants to write for TV. ‘That could be pretty cool,’ she says. She is very enthusiastic and laughs often. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. She notices how her imagination changes when she is in a different place. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busy places. But for now, New Zealand is her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more books.'

'When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. Now, for 40 years, he has been making guitars by hand. Jonny loves the guitar. He says, ‘How can two pieces of wood make a beautiful sound? Different wood makes different sounds. It still amazes me.’ Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at age eleven. At sixteen, he wanted a bass guitar. ‘Some people get a job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I wanted to make it myself. I learned how different shapes and wood make different sounds.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny made, but he and his brothers also made model boats and planes. ‘My father taught us to use tools,’ he says. Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. He liked painting and sculpture too. After school, he studied architecture at university. ‘Architecture is about design, which I liked,’ he says. But he left the course. ‘I wanted to do something different,’ he says. ‘Guitar-making is like sculpture. You make something people use.’ Jonny has made guitars for a living ever since. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for the cost of the materials. But as he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, Jonny says he is ‘still scratching a living’. He makes only ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings. In the early years, he went to music festivals to show his guitars. He learned how to price them by talking to musicians. Jonny thinks it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought only American guitars were good,’ he says. ‘But now UK guitars have a good reputation.’ Jonny says new guitar-makers should take courses, but also learn by trying things. ‘Look at other instruments and try different things,’ he says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn by yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’'

English people often talk about the weather. This is a common way to start a conversation. A famous writer, Dr. Johnson, said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting. But this is not true. The weather in England is not very exciting. There are no big storms like tornadoes or monsoons. 
Some people, like the writer Bill Bryson, say the English weather is boring. Others, like broadcaster Jeremy Paxman, say it is interesting because it is always changing. But the real reason English people talk about the weather is to start a conversation. Saying "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" is just a way to say hello or to fill a silence. 
English people use weather talk in three ways: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or to fill a pause when they don't know what else to say. This makes it seem like they talk about the weather a lot. But really, it is just a way to be friendly and talk to each other.

Alice Leader was in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was telling her class of 12- and 13-year-olds about the Romans building the wall. It is 120 km long and 5 meters high, built about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She could not find a good historical novel about life at the Wall, so she decided to write one herself.
Alice retired from teaching after 31 years and started writing in 2001. She said teaching is like acting, and it is very tiring. Writing is exciting but not as tiring. Her old teaching friends are jealous because she still connects with children through her books. Alice wants her books to be different from other children's books. She says many books for teenagers are about bad experiences or are total fantasy like Harry Potter. Her books are different.
Alice liked teaching English and History together. She loved making bored children interested. She sees writing as a way to keep teaching. She started writing her first novel because her sons were leaving home, and her head teacher suggested a writing course. At first, she did not want to do it, but she had to send a story to join the course. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and said she should publish it.
Alice asked for a year off from school to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor. He helped her edit the novel. Alice says they work well together. He helps with sentence structure, and she likes to add more scenes.

'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to have a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m excited,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done this before. The roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll stay warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. He wore winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair joked, ‘I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea on the way.’ The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Fleet Moss, the highest road in Yorkshire. Jonny had no problem with the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. They shook hands and started the race. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside, while Jonny drove the car on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. Who would get there first? Jonny had a problem right away. A big tractor came onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair wins, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving. Alistair had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. When he reached the top, he could ride fast again. Jonny had another problem. The roads were very narrow and slow. He drove through a small stream on the road. After the last village, he drove fast to the finish line. Neither brother knew where the other was. Jonny drove fast to Fleet Moss, while Alistair rode his bike across the last field and onto the road. Alistair stopped at the finish line and asked, ‘Is he here?’ The crowd said no. Alistair was happy. A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said sadly. ‘I’m disappointed.’'

'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, it is very quiet. You bounce the ball on the soft grass; you serve it; you hit it and hear your own shot. The grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel away from the world. The silence helps me play better. I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence breaks with noise: clapping, cheering, people calling your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching me. I am very focused. I don’t think about the millions watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me it was the biggest tournament. At 14, I told my friends I would play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. Losing in 2006 was not so bad. I was happy to be there at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe I could win. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could do better. It was not my skills, but my mind that failed. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, my tough coach, usually does not comfort me. He even criticizes me when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry, that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it was my last chance. I know a sports career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important, and I missed a big one in 2007. Toni was right. I had another chance in 2008. I learned from my loss. This time, my mind was strong. I believed I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we did not talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, that space was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She loved Africa and wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa. She became a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist there. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made Jane famous with articles and TV shows about her work with chimpanzees. She wrote many books, including a popular one called "In the Shadow of Man," which is in 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. She helped us understand chimpanzees better. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. Jane showed that chimpanzees have emotions and social lives like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Jane's study of chimpanzees in Gombe, Nigeria, is a great scientific achievement. She changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane was curious. When she was five, she hid in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity was the start of her career as a biologist.'

'Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist. She can speak like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are known from children's TV, cartoons, and health and safety videos. Shirley says, ‘I just did a voiceover about back injuries, so I had to learn how to say many medical words.’ She talks about voiceover work. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and they can,’ she says. ‘But there is more to it. You have to make the script come alive for people who can’t see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceovers, but they don’t always get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course. She sang jingles for TV ads. One day, a man at the recording studio asked her to try a rabbit voice for a cartoon. She thought it was funny but tried it and got a big part. Shirley found out she could do voices and wanted to do voiceover work. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I played the main character and her brother and mother.’ Female actors often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. It is hard to hire child actors, so companies prefer adults. Shirley learned to make different child voices by watching children’s TV. She does many jobs, like educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound happy about things you don’t care about,’ she says. ‘But I learned to smile while talking to make my voice sound happy. Animation work is fun because I work with other actors.’ The competition is tough, and a good showreel is important. ‘It’s worth making a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists with this.’ She says she succeeded through hard work and talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel or practising voices, it’s about setting goals and not giving up.’ Shirley suggests going to ‘specialist workshops’ for voiceover work. She loves voices and becomes the characters she plays. ‘If I do an American voice, I might speak like that for hours or days,’ she says. ‘My children are used to me talking in different voices.’'

'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more realistic jobs, like being a lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make money by drawing doodles like the ones in school notebooks seems silly. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted political cartoons. I drew some ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to live. You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, much money, or even to know how to draw well. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it was that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. Being a cartoonist is hard. You should only try it if you feel you can't do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and gives time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious. What about the business side of being a cartoonist? Many cartoonists used to find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but not good at business. Some people are afraid others will steal their ideas, even if they have never sold a cartoon. They don’t let others see their work! To protect your work, you can draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular on the internet, it can be a lucky break!'

'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house. I decided to throw away an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was black and made in Japan. I usually keep old things, so why did I want to throw it away? I took it to the rubbish dump. A young man saw me and asked, ‘You’re not going to throw that away, are you?’ I said yes, and he asked if he could have it. I said ‘Yes’, and we went our separate ways. Later, I felt sad about what I did. A few months ago, I got an email from a man named Keith Rushton. He said, ‘I’ve got your electric guitar.’ The guitar was sold many times, but Keith found my name on it. He found me online and offered to sell it back to me. I was very happy. My dad used to put name stickers on my things, like my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s. I liked the sound, but I didn’t get very good. So, I switched to the electric guitar. It was the time of punk music, and you didn’t have to play well to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. It felt smaller than I remembered. I played it again, and my fingers remembered the chords. Now, I want to play in a band. My son plays the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people like me and call our band ‘The Regainers’!'

'People are talking a lot about sleep now. I wrote a book called Insomniac about people who cannot sleep well. I said that not sleeping enough is bad for our mind, body, and mood. People who cannot sleep know how important sleep is. It is good that sleep is getting attention. But what about dreams? We do not hear much about dreams. We lose dreams when we wake up early. The last part of sleep is called REM, or 'Rapid Eye Movement'. This is when we dream the most. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of sleep time in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM. When people do not get REM sleep, they have more REM sleep the next night. This shows dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM. Many agreed with Sigmund Freud, who said dreams help us understand our mind. But later, researchers did not find this to be true. Now, dream study looks at the physical side of dreams. There is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold from Harvard University. Dreams are important. P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams more than other people. He says people who like to be creative use dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers use dreams because films are like dreams. But I think everyone needs dreams, not just artists. Everyone needs to think creatively. Dreams help us think in new ways. Stickgold says dreams help us find new ideas. When people wake up from REM, they have more original ideas. This is creativity, says Stickgold. I write better after dreaming. Even a bad dream helps me think. Creativity is not just for artists. We all need to think creatively in our lives. This is why we need to dream.'

'Susie Ray left London 20 years ago. She moved to a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you see empty frames and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a famous copyist artist. She can paint like famous artists from the past, like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her paintings look so real that art experts think they are the originals. The real paintings are worth millions, but Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000. She paints for galleries and private collectors. Some people pretend her copies are real. Susie always signs her name on the back of her paintings. It is against the law to sell a copy as the real thing. Susie used to work as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She learned to be very accurate. Now, she tells young artists to learn to draw well. Susie likes painting French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. She says their art is hard to copy because it is both quick and careful. Susie does not paint her own art because she likes copying. She once tried painting fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist.'

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea and wanted to be the fastest sailor. She started sailing when she was a child. Ellen felt very close to her boats. When she was on land, she missed the ocean and wanted to sail again. She raced alone around the world in the Vendée Globe and came second. Her boat, Kingfisher, was her home for 94 days. She planned everything carefully, like how much food and supplies she needed. Ellen took care of her boat because her life depended on it.
Later, Ellen went to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. She helped with a bird survey and saw old whaling stations. This made her think about how people use up resources and move on. Ellen believes we need to save the planet. She says we should not use up things like coal, oil, and gas because they are limited. Instead, we should reuse things.
Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation. It helps young people learn about a sustainable future. She talks to factories and governments about using resources wisely. Ellen says this work is important and different from sailing. She misses the adventure of the sea but feels her new work is more important.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old. He wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people play on computers and games, but Jordan wants to inspire kids to go outside. Jordan's team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is part of their big goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he is 20.
Some famous climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young climber might be strong, but they worry if a teenager is ready emotionally. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to be safe. The Romeros know people say this. Paul says, ‘I know people criticize us, but we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.’
I wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it his father’s idea? Paul says, ‘This is not about me. Jordan talked about it for the future, but we thought: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him to make sure he still wants to do it.’ When I ask Jordan why he likes the challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on my goal.’
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is a record challenge. This is a problem for Jordan. People might say that winning is more important than having fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story. This means writing online, taking photos, and giving interviews. He has to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, ‘If Jordan wants to stop climbing and play basketball, we will stop this project and go to the gym.’

'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they don’t know who he is. I am studying music at university, but my classmates don’t know much about classical music either. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have their music. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and classical CDs sell only about 300 copies each. It’s hard to believe. Why don’t people like classical music anymore? Older people say it’s because of TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s true. Classical music doesn’t interest most people, especially teenagers. Teenagers buy most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. I play in an orchestra, but I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but I don’t listen to much classical music. Why don’t teenagers like classical music? Classical music changes mood a lot, and we like things fast. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is good for pop songs but not for classical music. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, and it talks about things teenagers care about. Classical music is powerful but doesn’t talk about teenage issues. How we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home, and concerts were the only other way to hear music. Now, we can find any music online, but we don’t often listen to classical music. When did you last hear classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people go to classical concerts now, but not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why more people like classical music when they are older, but if teenagers’ parents like something, they usually don’t. Some say schools are to blame, but many kids like playing classical music in school orchestras. They practice a lot, but when they relax, they choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to the school. Her mother didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Almonside was a strange school with many buildings hidden among trees. Mrs. Wyndham saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre. "Riding centre," said Bonnie, interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a path between trees. "Walk beside me," said Mrs. Wyndham, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so. 
A few minutes later, her mother talked to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office. Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be in trouble soon anyway," she thought, "so why not start now?" She left and went to the riding centre. There was a nice building for the horses and a big place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She liked horses and treated them with respect. The horses looked well cared for. She walked along, looking at each horse. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony. The next horse surprised her. "You’re the best!" she said. He was brown with a little white. Lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," she said, petting him. "In my dreams, I was riding you in a big competition." His name was Maverick.
Bonnie wanted to ride him. "Where can I find a bridle and saddle?" she wondered. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked. She was happy to find it. She put a saddle on Maverick and forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said. "I know about horses, even if I don’t know about other things." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The ride was exciting, and the wind felt nice on her face. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old boy from Australia. He is famous for his music. Cody started playing the guitar when he was six years old. He began writing songs at seven. Cody also liked swimming and surfing. When he was 13, he posted videos of himself singing online. Many people liked his videos and wanted to see more.
Cody was a good swimmer and trained with top coaches. But music companies wanted to work with him. Cody had to choose between swimming in Australia or moving to the US for music. He decided to move to the US with his family.
Cody's family supports him, but they stay out of the spotlight. He thinks it is important to have good people around him. Sometimes, Cody worries about his little brother and sister because they travel a lot and do not have a normal life. But his family always supports him.
Cody is happy to travel and play music for many fans. He knows this success might not last forever, but he is grateful for the chance.

'I jumped out of bed and looked out the window at the river. The ice on the river was starting to crack in the morning sun. I looked at the sandbags that were there to stop the water from flooding the buildings. My back hurt from helping to put them there last week. I worked with many people from the town. My grandfather didn’t notice much. I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to walk on the ice. I put on my kayaking wetsuit and checked my pocket for a silver chain. My grandfather gave it to me from a trip to South America. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it at night. I went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I almost bumped into Grandpa in the hallway. ‘Watch where you’re going,’ he said. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘I’m going kayaking,’ I said. Grandpa gets angry sometimes. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. I took a deep breath. He went into the bathroom. Mom said, ‘Don’t mind him. He’s not himself.’ When I was a child, he was my hero. He has photos in National Geographic magazine. I want to be in that magazine too. Mom smiled. ‘Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination!’ I smiled back. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. I ate my banana and went to the boathouse.'

Mum held Jess's arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table was a painting by Grandpa. It was not finished. "Do you know about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I have never seen it before," she said. The painting showed a river. It was not a real river, maybe a fantasy one. The picture was strange but beautiful. There were no animals or people. It felt right that way. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Grandpa never named his pictures. Mum turned the picture over. Jess read the words: "River Boy." There was no boy in the picture. "Strange, isn’t it?" Mum said. "Maybe he will add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You should not have asked." "I know, but it is unusual. You can guess what he said." Jess knew. Grandpa always said it is not the artist's job to explain a painting. Each picture has its own life. "I hoped you might know something about this painting," Mum said. "You seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" Jess knew the word. Grandpa used it when she watched him paint. But she thought he meant a goddess, not her. "He does not need me to inspire him," she said. "He has been painting all his life."

'This morning, I did not plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I am not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. Maybe if I tripped with Dad’s knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet. I did not wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is small, white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept china ornaments in it. I keep shells, fossils, and stones there. I was happy when Gran gave it to me! But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It needs to be in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom. My room is small, under the roof, and shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I will be in my small room for a long time. I don’t mind; I like my little room. It’s cosy, like a nest. The roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The only problem is, there are not enough corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a bit too tall. If I could cut a few centimetres off the bottom... Then I thought, if I can’t cut the cabinet, maybe I can cut the carpet. It seemed like a good idea. Dad calls this lateral thinking. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. That is what I was doing!'

'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of very small people who live hidden in a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to make a TV show of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the show to be from the Borrowers' view, not a human one, which made filming harder. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the Borrowers' world, the crew had to film from very low down, no higher than 15 centimetres, to get their view. We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was making the shadows look right when the tiny Borrowers were shown with normal-sized backgrounds. We found a special way to do this. After the show was on TV, a famous US film director, George Lucas, called to ask how I did it. The only set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, with big objects to make the actors look small. It was very strange. When I asked them to carry big things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act. One important thing was getting the costumes right. I made them from heavy material so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the main actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit down during breaks, and she couldn’t take the dress off because it was sewn on every morning. The trousers for the main actor were made from a rug, as normal material would look too smooth. The weather was very hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for the costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to act with things that weren't there. I drew pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked. We didn’t have money for special effects during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work fast – I once filmed a whole scene without film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the show was good at showing the magic of the books.'

'Mom stops the car at my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, but there are no journalists. I tell her, ‘Everything’s going to be fine.’ She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. I am alone now at this new school. I wanted to come here to meet real kids. My dad is in a band, and we used to travel a lot. But now we are staying here. I walk into the school office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule, please,’ I say to the secretary. ‘Name?’ she asks. ‘Desert McGraw,’ I reply. She looks confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types on her keyboard. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One second, it’s printing,’ she says. She gives me the paper. My first class is English Literature. I like English. It is my favorite subject. I go to Room 214 on the second floor. I hear the teacher calling names. I sit down quietly. The girl next to me smiles. ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look at my shoes. They are expensive. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher calls my name, ‘Desert McGraw?’ ‘Here,’ I answer. The teacher is Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. Then she lets us talk to each other. ‘Why did you move here?’ the girl asks. I think about what to say. My dad wanted to record a new album here. ‘My dad had to relocate,’ I tell her. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say. ‘Cool. I’m Becca,’ she says. She doesn’t seem to care much. Great.'

'Today, American teenage girls have many things to do. They need to be good at school, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in everything. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and do nothing special. They have a lot of homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, and chores at home. They also try to have a social life. Kristen, a teenager, says people forget how much pressure teenagers have. Even with all this work, people still think teenagers are lazy and only care about themselves. Kristen says this is not true. She uses her phone to help with her work, not just for fun. Teenagers need to be connected all the time. They use phones and tablets to do homework anywhere. Schoolwork does not stop at school; it needs attention all the time. Many teenagers wake up at 6 or 7 a.m. and go to bed after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They do not get enough sleep. Only 20% of teenagers get the nine hours of sleep they need. Some teenagers fall asleep in school because they are so tired. Lindamarie, another teenager, says she has only 18 hours of free time a week. She uses this time to volunteer, not just for social media or TV. She likes helping others and making a positive impact. In the future, teenagers will continue to show they are not just lazy or selfish. They will keep changing the world, even before they finish school.'

'The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. This group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. It is a science project and an adventure, which is why teenagers like it. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are going to release a high-altitude balloon to try to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, making a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank is used to fill the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy drove seven hours to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time to let the balloon go. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they say, and the balloon goes up. Some of them run and watch it with flashlights until it is gone. There is quiet and a feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. The lunch box usually lands far from people. ‘Recoveries are a big part of the program,’ says the group’s leader. They have lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘We learn about the land this way,’ he says. This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. The team had to drive around the mountains to get it. They had to decide if driving or walking was better. It could be hard if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘These students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to them.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was on a rock in a waterfall. The camera did not record any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but it was a chance to talk about atmospheric waves.
