And it was another adventure story to share.'

Chloe Morgan did not like science or Palaeontology much until she was fifteen. It happened by accident. Her younger brother liked dinosaurs, but Chloe did not. She helped him with a science project and read an article about new dinosaur discoveries. This made her very interested in Palaeontology. 
Chloe met a famous palaeontologist named Matt Cornelius. She was nervous, but he was friendly and listened to her questions. This made her feel better.
Chloe talks about how movies show palaeontologists. She says movies like Jurassic Park make people interested in dinosaurs, but they do not show real palaeontologists well. In movies, they are shown as strange or funny people. Chloe says her job is different. She digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs, and writes for science magazines. She also talks to people about science.
Chloe thinks it is important to teach young people about science. She likes to talk about dinosaurs to get children interested in the natural world. This helps them learn about other science topics.
Chloe helped with a TV show called Walking with Dinosaurs. She checked that the dinosaurs shown were correct. The show was popular because it showed dinosaurs in a new way.
Chloe thinks dinosaurs are interesting because they make us want to explore and discover new things. They remind us there is still much to learn about the world. Palaeontology is like time travel to her.

"I will say this one time: when you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know you are not 'there yet' when you ask 'Are we there yet?' When you arrive, it is not 'there' anymore. It is 'here.' So, you should ask 'Are we here yet?' Parents want to be 'there' more than kids do. Kids should enjoy sitting in the back seat. You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while looking out the window. Mum or dad is in the front seat, giving juice boxes and cookies, and changing the radio. They make sure everything is okay. Are we there yet? I hope not. But sometimes, my brother Tim does something bad, like putting his foot on my side. I put my foot on his side. Then we fight. Mum and dad stop us and tell Tim to stay in his seat. We calm down. Then, I feel air on my arm. Tim is blowing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks it is okay. I get angry. Tim gets in trouble again. Dad has ideas to keep us quiet. When we ask 'Are we there yet?' he says, 'Yes, get out of the car.' But we are still on the highway. So, we know we are not there yet. You know you are 'there' when mum and dad get out of the car and walk away from us. So remember: if mum and dad can still answer your question, you are not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK. In their café, people can drink coffee, eat cake, and play board games. John and Zuzi want people to have fun and come back again. Zuzi says they started the café because people use phones and gadgets too much. They want people to talk and be together without screens.
In the café, people play games called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was Catan, made by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In Catan, players build settlements and trade resources. Everyone stays involved until the end. Later, 'co-operative' games were made, where players work as a team. One popular game is Pandemic, made by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players solve global problems together.
Matt Leacock loved board games as a child, even though some games were disappointing. With his uncle, he tried to make better games. Pandemic became very popular. It has a lot of storytelling, like video games. Players develop characters and the story changes.
Video games helped board games become popular. Many people play games on their phones now. Ben Hogg, from a games company, says more people like playing games today. Before, people played video games together in the same room. Now, many video games are online, and players are not together. So, some people want to play games with others in person again.
John and Zuzi's café is busy and popular. Board games are more than just fun. In our online world, games are a way to be together in real life. This trend will continue.

Jamie Scott is a famous music writer and producer from the UK. His story shows why working hard is important in music. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him guitar. At home, he listened to a radio station for older people, which influenced him. He first heard a modern song when he was 12. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis and music. He played tennis very well, but he loved music more. At 17, he left school to become a musician. He was in a music duo with a friend, but his friend did not want to make music a career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to write songs and play music. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. He got a music deal at 19 because of one song, but he had to leave his friend to be a solo artist. Jamie found success writing songs for others, not performing. He says he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but in the right place as a writer. He helps new artists by writing songs that can be big hits. Jamie wants to write songs that many people will listen to. He believes in writing great songs that can be popular. Jamie is honest about wanting to write number one songs. He knows he is good at it and focuses on making the best music. He wants to write classic modern pop songs.

'Tony Connor is a new kind of famous person. He is very popular online, but many people who do not watch online videos might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist'. This means he rides his bike in difficult places, like on roofs or walls. People film his tricks and put them online. 
I met Tony in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. Many local boys knew him, and even older people came to say he is 'a legend'. After watching him, I agreed. Tony is brave and creative. Before each trick, he tells me what he will do, and I am surprised when he does it. But when I say nice things to him, he does not seem very happy. 
Tony is famous because of the internet, but he does not like being a celebrity. He says, 'I find it hard to talk to fans. I like doing things more than talking about them.' This is funny because his fame comes from social media and cameras. He says, 'This technology helps me make money.' But he also thinks people spend too much time with cameras and screens. 
Tony makes good money from his videos. In the past, this would only be a hobby. I learned that to be a top athlete, you need energy and the ability to keep going after failure. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but kept trying until he succeeded.
Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people do not understand his sport. He gets advice from experts to stay safe. Tony is careful about risks. He says, 'Some people never get scared, but they should be careful. I feel fear but find a way to overcome it. I plan a lot before trying a new trick. I must be confident before I jump. If I am sure, then I am okay.''

'Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous things for charity. She ran a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net. She had a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. She found out that high-wire walking was very different from other circus skills she knew. ‘The training was a surprise’, said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill. Then, I did exercises for an hour, and another hour after practising on the wire. I also learned how to fall onto the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she walked step by step on the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But Helen is still planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

'In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing. A penny farthing is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Jeff had already written a book about traveling in Canada in an old car. He loved motor sports and worked on racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even went to Amsterdam on it for a holiday. ‘That trip made me want to see the world by bike,’ he says. Jeff didn’t want a normal bike, so he decided to build a penny farthing himself. He went to a museum to learn how to make one. After two tries in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally left in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was seeing Mount Everest in Tibet. ‘I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I went, the more people were amazed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and stayed in bed for ten days without medicine. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. But Jeff says, ‘if I had the money, I would travel again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’'

'I work at a university in the US. My team and I study water birds, especially the American black duck. We have a new tool called a 'night-vision scope'. It helps us see ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because there are fewer of them now. We don't know if they have enough food on the east coast. We know what they do in the day, but not at night. We didn't have the right tools before. But now, with the new scope, we can see clearly, even when there is no moon. This will help us learn more and take care of their home better. The work is hard. There are four of us, and we work six hours every day. We study ducks in different places. I sometimes take a boat to see ducks and write notes. The weather is not always good. Some nights are nice, but many are wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We only missed one day of work because of deep snow. I like the challenge, even though summer will be different. In summer, we will be inside a lab looking at our results. It will be hard to stay inside, but it is important. I love my work and wouldn't change it!'

'When I tell people about my job, they can't believe it. But it's true! I eat chocolate for my job. I taste chocolate to make sure it is good for customers. Every week, I get small pieces of chocolate from our factory. I check them for taste, feel, and smell. I also taste the nuts and fruit we use. I choose the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen. I test and taste chocolate there. I give my work friends some chocolate too! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients. It is nice to have my own space. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I am in the food lab. Other times, I travel to buy ingredients. I have a young family, so traveling can be hard. But I like the change and not having a routine. I love the chocolate most! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I still like to eat it. I even eat more chocolate at home in the evening!'

'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many things, like juggling, throwing and catching balls or even fire, and trapeze, which is flying through the air. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can watch some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia says, “For a circus job, performers need to do different things all the time – it’s important to keep shows exciting. If you want to be good in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great thing is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is important, but the best performers want success, have imagination, and always try to get better. People often think you might get hurt or only work a little each year. But really, you need to think about the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other jobs.” The course also teaches business planning. Many students start businesses around the world and like to share their stories. Sophia warns, it’s not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but a lot of fun!”'

'You may not know her name or her face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a backing singer. She sings behind the main singer. Some people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers. That is not true – they have to be very good. People like Mariam are important in the music world! ‘What I love about my job is that when I go to the recording studio, I never know what I will sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask. One time, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘I need to be very good at music for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to look at. I will never forget my first time recording music for a film. It was very hard because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already.’ ‘One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. New songwriters do not always know which music is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can learn how to make it better.’'

'Julie Deane started with little fashion knowledge and made a successful business with her 'satchels' - a traditional school bag. These bags are now sold in famous shops and are popular with celebrities. Before choosing satchels, Julie thought about different businesses, like cake decorating and party planning. Not everyone agreed with her choice, but Julie believed in her idea. She worked with her mother, who had a natural talent for business, and got design ideas from children's storybooks. Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her a lot. At first, she sold one satchel a week. To get attention, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them. They did, and interest grew. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity has a satchel. Instead of spending money on online ads, she uses the internet for new style ideas. There was a problem when another company copied her design, so now she trusts her production team. People say her office has a positive feeling, and everyone loves working there. There is a new factory, but the team makes it special.'

'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky chose to do many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling and bought a special bike for races. He started joining competitions. Vicky thought it looked fun and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was near her school, so she could train after school every day. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. Then, when she was 28, she stopped racing. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions, but I got a bit tired. When the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new job.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who don’t like sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together.’ The charity uses famous people to talk about their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people think celebrities only help to make themselves look good, and this hides the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’'

'Ana Ronson is a singer and songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher helped her off the stage. The teacher said she should join the school theatre club to feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in three days. She liked it so much that she joined a songwriting course. She was the youngest student but knew a lot about music. Ana wrote a song called Something to Say because she was annoyed that the teacher did not listen to her. She put the song online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the words. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, came to ask her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was not sure because she did not know the company and did not want someone to tell her what to sing. But Joss said this would not happen, and soon she sang at a concert in Dublin for Isotope. All the tickets sold quickly, and it was a great night. Ana likes to write songs about difficult times because she has more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him sad. Ana hopes people like her songs, but she wants to write about things that are important to her.'

'Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat with a group along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not. I wanted to visit the area because I saw it on TV when I was a child. Our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I asked Harry if I could go too, and he said yes! A few days before we left, there were storms where we were going. But the weather was good when we got there. I was busy at work, so I did not have much time to plan. But Harry said he took care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our things into small boats, and left. The guide said not many people live on that coast. On the first morning, we only saw dolphins and birds. There were islands far away, but it was foggy, so we could not see them well. I looked at the nice patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped to look at the rock pools on the beaches. They had many colorful fish. I did not know many of them. It was nice not to worry about time. We always made lunch and dinner together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. The beds were hard, but it was very relaxing! When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I also wanted to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

'My dad was a basketball player in Germany, like his father. I watched many of his games when I was a kid. You might think I would love basketball, but I didn't. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, but I took a book to read instead of watching the games. When I started secondary school, I was not a teenager yet, but I was already two metres tall. My sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed more skills to play a real match. The teacher believed in me, and a few weeks later, I played against another school. My mum and dad came to watch, which made me nervous, but it was OK! For the next four years, I practised every day and did well. I joined an adult team before moving to a sports academy in the USA at fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic players, and it was great to work with him. I missed my parents, but I got used to my new life, and my English got better! I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after going to the USA. I was taller than most players, but I needed to gain weight. My coach knew a team for me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.'

'Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college. I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I decided to become a weekend tour guide in my city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and I liked it a lot. I saw my city in a new way. After I finished my studies, I wanted to be a full-time tour guide. I learned that I needed a licence. To get it, I had to know many things about Chicago, like its buildings, history, and transport. After some months, I got my tour guide qualification. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts. You need to be fun and tell good stories. You also need to handle changes, like if a place is closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy the tour. If they are happy, they write good reviews online. Good reviews bring more customers. I try to make my tours fun and stress-free. Because of this, my reviews are usually very good, and people recommend my tours to others visiting Chicago.'

My name is Ella and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Josie is five years younger than me. We went to help at a place for elephants. This place helps sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would like the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing this. But in the end, it was okay.
Our main job was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants. This took most of the day. Josie thought it was hard work, but I liked seeing the elephants happy. We also washed the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun, even if I got very wet!
In the evening, we took the elephants to the forest where they stayed at night. All the volunteers lived in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we knew it would be like that. The food was very good and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, we talked and played games with the other volunteers and staff.
Now we are back in the UK. Josie does not talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her, she says she loved it. I think she is a bit sad because she missed her friends too much. But she knows she was lucky to go there. Maybe she will go back one day. I want to go back for sure!

'I’m Gina D’Costa and I have a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many people. Some people buy flowers for friends or for their homes. Hotels and offices also buy flowers. Sometimes, we help with photo sessions for businesses by giving flowers for their pictures. One time, I put flowers in a castle for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very happy with it. My day starts at 4 a.m. I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still sleeping then. My friends think I am crazy, but I love my work. It is often cold and dark, but I don’t mind. The flower market is great, with flowers from all over the world. There are many colors and smells. If I chose for myself, I would get pink flowers because pink is my favorite color. But I have to remember that other people like different flowers. Not all flowers are available all year. I don’t like arguing about prices with the flower-sellers, but it is part of the job. Flowers are not cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and put flowers in vases. Then we make flower bunches and decide how much they cost. Customers are often surprised by the price, and I sometimes ask them to choose again. Some people think this is too much work, but I like making nice flowers for the money people want to spend. That’s what you do when you sell things – I wouldn’t want any other job!'

'My city has a modern cinema that shows all the new films I want to see. It also shows many films for kids on the weekends. The cinema is close to my home. But a year ago, I wanted to talk about films with people after watching them. So, I started a film club with two friends! We did not want to use a cinema to show films. Instead, we pick a new place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film about Antarctica. It was very cold, which was perfect for the film! Some places are free because they sell snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We just want to cover our costs, not make money. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own equipment. We sell tickets online, so we know how many people are coming. There is still a lot to do, but when people say they had a great time, it feels wonderful. Our website helps us connect with other film clubs in the country. We visit them to see how they do things, but we love our own club! We started a blog because people look online for film information. We also put posters in cafés. But the best way is when people tell their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we do with each film. Last month, we had a movie quiz, and everyone enjoyed it.'

'When I was a child, I loved taking photos. At 15, I wanted to do something special with my hobby. I decided to take one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I liked the idea. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to make a photo diary and show my photos to others. I was happy to see that people liked my photos. I enjoyed taking photos of many things. Someone told me to focus on one topic to make my project better. I agreed and started taking photos of nature, like birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different because other young photographers took color photos. Sometimes I doubted my project and almost stopped. But I trusted myself and felt better about my style. I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photo competition for people my age. I entered my photos for fun. I was so happy when I won first prize. It was the first time I thought my photography was good. Now, I have my own photo studio and I am happy with my career choice.'

'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year. I wanted to try camping, sailing, and learn new skills like public speaking. In the NYC, you can do many activities and learn new things. There are different levels: beginner to advanced. Adult volunteers, called ‘leaders’, help you. When you finish a level, you get a certificate. 
When I joined, my leader said I should help at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was not sure because I went to that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and other children already had friends, so I stopped going. But I wanted my first NYC certificate, so I tried the challenge. Soon, I loved spending time at the children’s club. It was more than just getting a certificate. After the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep helping at the club. I made good friends with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week and I really enjoy it.
Because of the children’s club, I want to be a youth worker when I finish school in three years. A youth worker is someone who works with children. I never thought about this job before. I have learned a lot at the club and improved my communication skills. I have many NYC certificates now, and one is for camping!'

'I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort, two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to encourage me to try snowboarding. I was young and did not think about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to try. He made it look easy. In the end, I did well. After this, I loved snowboarding and got better at it. I started competing when I was ten. Some people do many competitions and get bored, but I still love it. I like winning too, and this makes me try harder. I enjoy not having a fixed plan. Once, I got a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I was not sure I would try the jumps, but I did, and it was great. This made me trust myself more. In the summer, I train and study because there is no snow. I train every day, but I do not have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend time with my friends. It helps me when I cannot snowboard. I think about my future. Snowboarding is important to me, but I need another plan if I do not become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I wonder if I can be a doctor if I have time for college. I love snowboarding, but I know I cannot do it forever.'

'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had. I did not think about the future. For example, I did not know what job I wanted after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday. I wanted a new phone too. My parents said I could have it if I paid for it myself. So, I decided to work part-time and save money. I learned a lot from this. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I did not like it. My parents said I could start my own small business. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try. I thought it was hard, but it was easy for me. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked it. Mum showed me how to make nice things at home. I sold my first jewellery to friends and family. They said they liked them, but I thought they just wanted to be nice. I wanted to know if other people liked them too. So, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists bought my jewellery. Soon, people from all over the country called to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just me and my mum. Then, I knew it could work, so I made a website. Now, I make a lot of money from my business, mostly online. We still have our market stall too. It has been a lot of fun.'

'Janine Stuart wrote a book called Being Amelia when she was only 13 years old. The book became very popular. Being Amelia is a little bit about Janine’s life. Janine said, ‘My family moved a lot because of my dad’s job, so I learned to make new friends. I know how it feels to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, starting at a new school. Some funny parts of the book are about Amelia’s life at home, especially with her older brother. I don’t have brothers or sisters, so I used my imagination for that.’ Janine started writing her book one summer when she was bored. Her mom wanted to be a writer, and her teachers told her to write, so it was a good way for Janine to spend her time. The year before, she won a short story competition for young writers. So, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they wanted to read it. They liked it, and a year later, Janine’s book was in stores. One review of Being Amelia says that even though the cover has happy teenagers, the story is about people facing hard times, and this makes readers believe in them. The reviewer says Janine is young, and her book is not very long, but she is a better writer than some other famous authors. Janine is still getting used to being famous: ‘At first, I hid when people saw me in the street, but now it’s OK. I want to help other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just spend time with my friends, and then I have something interesting to write about!’'

'I’m Tom. I’m fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. My father got a job as the castle’s manager. He works for a group that takes care of old buildings and lets people visit them. He was happy about the job, but it took time for us to agree. We thought about living on the island. We knew the castle might not be as nice as our home across the water, and there was no school. After we moved, we got used to life on the island. The castle isn’t very pretty, but our apartment is nice. In summer, many people visit the island, and there are parties on the beach. In winter, we only see the other families on the island. There aren’t many teenagers, which I didn’t like. The adults help each other with fixing things, which is hard work. The biggest change for me was taking a boat to my old school every day. I wanted to go on stormy days with big waves, but the boats don’t go then! If I miss the bus to the harbour after school, I miss the last boat home, which is a problem. So, when friends come home with me, I tell them to hurry! But we see great views, like the sunset over the sea. Some days, it’s so foggy you can’t see anything, then it’s sunny again. It’s amazing! We have bad storms, and I worry if the castle is strong enough. But it’s been here for a long time, and it’s still standing!'

'I live in a house in the countryside in Scotland. I love nature and animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family. We saw many birds there. I watched them with my parents. They showed me how to know different birds and where to see them. It was great! After we came home, I joined a birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different birds. I am close to this goal because on family holidays, I see birds from other countries too. We always look for places with birdwatching activities. I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America. I hoped to see my 200th bird there. I did not see it, but I learned to be patient. I posted a video online about my birdwatching. Many teenagers liked it and said it looked fun. My teachers saw it and asked me to talk about birdwatching at school. I was not nervous until I walked onto the stage. I had notes to help me, but the whole school and my friends were watching! I felt better when it was over. The teachers said I did well. I might do another talk next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why teenagers in cities might not think about birdwatching, but there are many birds to see, especially in green areas. Birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested. Everyone needs to connect with nature, and it does not have to cost much money.'

'I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and soon, I was not a bad player. My family knew I liked new hobbies and then stopped them, so they thought I would stop playing football too. But I did not stop. I dreamed of playing football as a job when I was older. The chance came sooner than I thought. I played in local games, and one referee saw I was a good player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She asked me to join her club. I was surprised – I did not know young girls could join women’s clubs. The manager liked me, and I started training with a big club when I was 13. I got much better. Some people still thought I would not be a star player, and that made me a bit sad. But the coach told me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in a big match! I ran very hard – I did not want the other players to blame me if we lost. By luck, I scored the winning goal. I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the field. It was fantastic! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are having a football tournament in my area. We want teenagers to like football and talk to other players in my club. They will see the professional environment and feel they can play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them is the same as my coach gave me – you will have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I have had very few bad times, so I have been lucky!'

'In the UK and other countries, schools and universities want students to start doing research early. Research is not just for famous scientists or big universities. It is a way to learn and build skills. Research helps in school and at work. It is about asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? 
Research can be big and complex, or it can be simple and about everyday things. Students have done research in school projects and at work. You ask questions and find answers when you plan a holiday, grow plants, fix things, or shop online.
In college, you need to ask questions, think about what you read, and make your own ideas. In some places, people think knowledge is already known, and you learn by listening to teachers. But in the UK, US, and other places, you should question what you learn. 
Critical thinking is important. You should not just repeat what you read. Think about it and see if it makes sense. Check if the information is true and backed by evidence. Do not just believe everything you read or hear.'

'Cities have always been places where people think and create. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In Paris, artist Pablo Picasso talked about art in cafés. But living in a city is not easy. The same London coffee houses also spread disease, and Picasso moved to the countryside. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural. Scientists are studying how cities affect our brains. They found that city life can make us tired and think less clearly. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that people in hospitals get better faster when they see trees. Even a little bit of nature helps our brains because it gives us a break from city life. More people now live in cities than ever before. We live in crowded places with many people around us. This can affect our mental and physical health. In a busy city, our brains have to pay attention to many things, like people walking and cars driving. This is tiring because our brains have to work hard to focus. Nature, on the other hand, is relaxing and helps our brains rest. This idea is called attention restoration theory. It says that being in nature helps our brains recover. Parks in cities, like Central Park in New York, give people a break from city life. A walk in a park can help our brains work better. People try many things to think better, like energy drinks, but being in nature is very helpful. Even though city life can be hard, cities still grow. They are places where people meet and share ideas. This makes cities creative. The busy streets and many people help new ideas happen. The challenge is to keep the good things about cities while reducing the stress they cause. Sometimes, people want to leave nature and go to the city for excitement.'

'Where is the mind? We might think the mind is only in our heads. Today, we have machines that can look inside the brain. But I think the mind is not just in the brain. Many things, like tools and writing, help us think. For example, a blind person uses a stick to feel. The stick becomes part of their body. This shows that the mind can be outside the head. I have a new idea called Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET says that things like tools and symbols help us think. They change how we think over time. Humans use tools to learn and understand the world. This makes our minds grow and change. MET helps us see how things like stone tools and smartphones change our minds. Humans have always used things to help them think, from the past to now.'

'Photography has changed how we see the world. In the United States, photography became very important. It is used in many ways: for science, industry, art, and fun. Some people say photography is the best thing the US gave to art. Photography started in the mid-19th century. Why did people like it? First, photography was a new technology. People in the US liked new things. Like trains and electricity, photography helped people see the world. Second, people used cameras to show who they were. Photos helped people and families keep memories. Photos look real, which matched the US artists' style of showing real life. A photo shows what the photographer wants us to see. Photos are made by machines, so they are records of what was in front of the camera. But, because a person takes the photo, it also shows their view. People think photos are a 'universal language' because we can understand them easily. But photos can mean different things. We need to know why the photo was taken and how people first saw it. The same photo can mean different things at different times. Artists now use photos in their work. For example, Andy Warhol used photos in his art. Photography is now a big part of art, just like painting.'

'In 1890, William James, an American thinker and doctor, called psychology the 'science of mental life.' This is still a good way to start understanding psychology today. We all have thoughts and feelings, so we know a little about this. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is mostly about humans. James thought human psychology had basic parts: thoughts and feelings, the world around us, and how we know about these things. This knowledge is personal and comes from our own thoughts and experiences. Sometimes, we think we know why people act a certain way, like feeling sad or quitting a job. But people can see things differently. Psychology tries to find out which ideas are right. Psychologists help us see the difference between our own ideas and scientific facts. They study the mind and brain, but they do not know everything about how the brain works. So, they learn by watching how people act. Psychology is like solving a puzzle. It uses clues from what we see and measures them carefully. Psychology wants to describe, understand, predict, and change things. It helps in many areas, like teaching children to read or helping people talk about their feelings. People have talked about psychology for a long time, but it has been studied scientifically for about 150 years. Early psychologists looked at their own thoughts to find answers. This was not always helpful. Today, psychologists watch how people behave to learn more.'

'In a simple building in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum has many products that people did not want to buy. The museum is owned by a company called GfK. Carol Sherry, who works at the museum, thinks each product has a sad story. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who used to work in marketing, wanted to collect new products. He started doing this in the 1960s. He found out that most products do not succeed. So, his collection became mostly products that failed. Many people like to think positively, even if things might not go well. Some people believe that if you imagine good things, they are more likely to happen. But research shows that thinking too much about success can make people less motivated. Psychologist Carol Dweck says that how we think about our abilities affects how we deal with failure. Some people think abilities are fixed, while others believe they can grow with effort. People who think abilities can grow see failure as a chance to improve. This way of thinking can make people happier.'

**Text for A1 Level:**
Sports teams often play better at home. But why? People have different ideas. Sports are changing a lot now. Two things make us think about home advantage: science and money. 
Sports scientists study why players do well. They have many ideas about home advantage. People with money want to know if home advantage is important. They think if players get paid a lot, they should play well anywhere.
Fans are important too. For example, Manchester United fans in England think their team needs their support. Fans believe they help their team score goals. But sometimes, the team does not score even when fans cheer loudly.
One thing is true: fans can affect referees. In an experiment, referees watched a game with and without crowd noise. Referees with noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows fans can influence referees.
Home advantage is less now than before. In the 1890s, home teams won 70% of the time. Now, they win 60%. Travel is easier now, and stadiums are similar.
Different sports have different home advantages. Basketball has a big home advantage, football too. Baseball has the smallest home advantage. In basketball, teamwork is important, and playing at home helps.
Another reason for home advantage is players feel more confident at home. Their testosterone levels are higher before home games. This makes them want to defend their home. In the Rugby World Cup, home teams sometimes won against stronger teams.
In sports, playing at home can be like "the law of the jungle."

"‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player many years ago. This saying is famous in sports. It means: ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate. This debate asks if talent is something you are born with or something you learn. Many people think practice is more important than talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson says you need 10,000 hours of practice to be an expert. Books like Outliers and Talent Is Overrated agree with this idea. But, in his book, Epstein says it is not always true. He looks at why some people are very good at what they do. He travels to places like Kenya and Alaska to find answers. In Alaska, he learns that sled dogs’ success might be because of their genes. This shows that both nature (genes) and nurture (practice) are important. Epstein says both are needed for success. He also talks about race and gender in sports. He asks why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. This shows the topic is complex."

'A new report says many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why children feel this way. In her book, Kith, she says children stay inside too much, watching TV or using computers. They do not play outside in nature, like in the woods or by rivers. This is a big problem, she thinks. 
A study talked to children and found they want to play outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their childhoods fondly. They played outside, swam in ponds, and built dens. They think this was better and healthier than how children live now. But these adults also keep their own children inside because they worry about safety.
Griffiths talks about how parents' fear helps toy companies sell more gadgets. She also mentions how some children are given medicine for being restless or have to wear goggles for games. She is not sure how common these things are, but she is very passionate about them.
Griffiths believes children should have freedom to explore and take risks. She says children need small accidents to learn. But she does not say how to make sure these accidents are small. Also, not all children want to explore. Some are shy and like to stay home. Maybe the real problem is making all children do the same thing, whether staying inside or going outside.'

'I am a scientist who studies the mind and behavior. I went to school for a long time. I am good at solving problems, but not because of school. Most problems in life need experience, not just school learning. For children, this experience comes from playing. My research is about how play helps children grow. All young animals, including humans, play. Animals that need to learn more, play more. For example, animals that hunt play more than animals that eat plants. Children play more than other young animals because they have a lot to learn. Play helps children learn important skills. These skills are not taught in school. They learn to think creatively, work with others, and control their feelings. Creativity is important for success. We need people who can solve new problems. Creative people often play. Albert Einstein said school almost made him lose interest in math and science, but he found it again after school. He called his work 'combinatorial play'. We cannot teach creativity, but we can stop it by making school too strict. It is important to get along with others and work together. Children learn this by playing with other children. Play is something you choose to do. If you cannot stop, it is not play. In play, everyone must be happy to keep playing. School has become harder: less playtime, more homework, and more pressure for good grades. Outside school, adults control sports and play. This has changed slowly but a lot over time. Parents are more worried, and experts warn about dangers. People think children learn more from adults than from each other. But children need more play, not more school. We must let children play and explore. This helps them grow into strong adults for the future.'

'In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn help them talk directly to employers. This is different from the past when people had to stand outside offices with signs saying 'hire me'. But using social media can also lead to mistakes. For example, a young person in the US asked a marketing executive on LinkedIn to share her contacts. She was upset and said no, sending a mean reply that many people saw online. This story shows that using social media for jobs can be tricky. Many young people use Facebook and Twitter for fun, but using them for work is different. Some young people are too confident and make mistakes when talking to employers online. Employers say young people can seem rude or too familiar. This can make it hard for them to get jobs, even if they have the right skills. To contact someone on a professional site, say who you are and offer to help them. Do not send the same message to everyone, and be polite. Social media can help you find jobs, but you need to use it carefully.'

'It is hard to say what will happen to newspapers in the future. Since 2000, many UK newspapers have lost a lot of readers. In the USA, only 26% of people get their news from newspapers now, compared to 45% in 2001. Some people think newspapers will disappear in 15 years. But old media often survive. For example, theatre is still popular even with newspapers, cinema, and TV. Radio is still popular in the TV age. Cinema is still popular even with videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again. Newspapers were once new too. They became popular in the 19th century because of new technology like the steam press and telegraph. People started to want news regularly. In the past, people did not expect change. They only noticed big events like famine or disease. Journalism as a job started in the 19th century. Before that, people did not need news every day. Newspapers have a set format and schedule, which can be limiting. Online news is different. People can read news when they want and choose what interests them. Online news can update quickly and correct mistakes. There is no limit to how much can be written. But online news often focuses on being first and getting comments, not on understanding. In the past, news was shared in places like markets, where it was mixed with rumors. We might be going back to that. Newspapers have not always explained the world well. They might disappear, or they might help us understand the world better.'

'Humans are not like animals that see well at night. We need sunlight to see. Our eyes are made for the day. But we have changed the night by adding lights everywhere. This is called light pollution. Light pollution happens when lights shine up into the sky instead of down to the ground. This makes the night too bright and affects animals and people. For example, birds can get confused by bright lights and fly into buildings. Some birds sing at night because of the lights. Light pollution also affects our health because we need darkness to sleep well. Long ago, people used candles and lanterns, and the night was dark. Now, cities are very bright at night. This makes it hard to see the stars. We need darkness to remember our place in the universe and to keep our bodies healthy.'

'The boss of a big company said his workers can take as many holidays as they want. He got the idea from another company. His daughter sent him an email about it. The big company has 50,000 workers and does many things like finance, transport, and healthcare. The other company has 2,000 workers and does one thing. It might be easier for the smaller company to let workers take holidays because they know each other's work better. The boss of the big company said workers can take holidays if they are sure their work is done and it won't hurt the company. But is it really possible to be sure? When you come back from holiday, there is always more work to do. Some people might feel bad about taking holidays and not go at all. This can make them stressed and less productive. Also, workers might feel pressure from others about how long they take off. In some companies, people work late and might not take holidays even if they can. If workers don't have a set number of holidays, they might feel they can't take time off because they don't want to look lazy. Technology makes it hard to know when work stops and free time starts. The other company started this holiday idea because workers asked about it. They said if work hours are not clear, why should holiday time be? But if there are no set work hours, all hours could be work hours. Workers might feel they are always being watched. Laws give workers a minimum number of holidays because rest is important for health. The good things like happiness and creativity from taking holidays can happen without this new idea. So, is this holiday idea really good for workers?'

'Journal-based peer review is when experts check a scientific paper before it is published. This helps make sure the research is good. It can take a long time, sometimes up to a year. Is it worth the wait? Yes and no. The way we publish science is changing. I still think papers should be checked before they are published, but things are moving. Preprints are part of this change. Preprints are drafts of papers shared online before they are reviewed. They help share new results quickly so others can read and discuss them. Publishing in journals is often about fame and career growth, which can lead to problems. Scientists want to publish in top journals, but this can make them cut corners. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal, not just if it is good. This can depend on how interesting the topic is, not just the quality. Many people know these problems, but few want to change the system. Preprints might help because they are not a big change. Some think journals won't accept papers shared as preprints, but this is not true. There is also a worry that without review, bad science will be published, but this hasn't happened yet. Preprints are open for everyone to read and discuss. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, says preprints helped her share her work and get feedback. Preprints let scientists talk about their work with others around the world. They can also share results that are not new discoveries, which journals often ignore. Preprints make papers more read and cited. They focus on the work, not where it is published.'

'When I ask my students what a poem is, they often say ‘a painting in words’. Their answers don't satisfy me. One day, I asked them to choose an object and write about it in two ways. First, like a scientist, and second, as if the object is speaking. The second part was called ‘Poem.’ One student wrote: Poem I may look strange, but I help people breathe. I am used in emergencies for a short time. Most people never use me. The object? An oxygen mask. This choice helped the class see how poetry is different. The exercise was fun and led to good talks. When I was in school, poetry was hard for me. Poems seemed like puzzles. After school, many people read fewer poems. Sometimes, you see a poem and it dares you to read it. Often, it is confusing or disappointing. But you feel good for trying. What do we want from poems? Deep feelings, beautiful images, or clever words? Maybe. But for tears, we watch movies. For information, we read articles. Novels let us escape, paintings are nice to look at, and music is special. But poems can be unclear, like life. This doesn’t tell us what a poem is. If you search online, it says poetry is art with rhythm and sound. But the word ‘poem’ comes from Greek, meaning ‘a thing made.’ Poets say poems are like wild animals or machines. But these ideas don’t fully explain poems. Talking about poems helps us think differently. Poems can change how we see things. Like songs, poems can stay in our minds. Words can be powerful. A poem in a newspaper can stand out. It uses space that could be for something else. A poem is written and rewritten, but it is not made to sell. Poems are special and can surprise us.'

I bought my first metal detector after I got married. It cost £70, which was a lot of money. My wife, Marion, was happy when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. I like finding old things because it makes me feel connected to the past. After the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion. 
One rainy February afternoon, I went to a place with old farming tools. My detector beeped, and I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I dug in the mud and found a round, golden ball. I thought it might be brass, but it was a beautiful gold necklace called a torc. It looked like the Great Torc in the British Museum, from over 2,000 years ago.
I took it home and showed Marion. We didn't try it on because it was too special. I hid it in our house because I was worried. The law says I had to tell the authorities about it in 14 days. I showed it to a friend in the hospital and then took it to the council office. They checked it and sold it to my local council. Now, it is in the British Museum in London. I got £350,000, which I shared with the field's owner.
Finding the torc was amazing, but I still enjoy looking for other things. People ask if I will stop now, but I won't. It's like fishing; you always hope to find something bigger next time.

'I love sleeping when I travel, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. My friends plan their trips with many activities, like visiting museums and hiking. I smile and listen, but I don't say much. What would they think if they knew I plan time for naps in the afternoon and lazy mornings in bed? Sleeping better is a nice part of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept – more than 12 hours a day. There were noisy birds, but I still slept well. Far from home, I could sleep deeply and have nice dreams. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes easier. I think sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break. When we travel, we see and hear new things. We take in new cultures, music, and places. We process all this when we sleep, so sleep feels more intense. Sleep changes in different places. People talk about jet lag, but I think adjusting to new places is more about local habits than time zones. In Trinidad, people wake up early, rest when it's hot, and become active in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to get used to their sleep pattern. When I do, I feel like I belong. I remember a day in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all took naps. I understood why they had many pillows. I joined them and experienced the siesta, a Latin American tradition. Travel sleep is special because I remember it. Away from my normal routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds when I sleep in a new place. Slow travel means enjoying every moment, and sleep is the slowest activity. Maybe I should tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.'

'The woman looked away from the mirror. ‘What do you think? And be honest.’ Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a pretty bow. ‘I still think this one looks best on you,’ she said nicely. The woman made a face. ‘But it is so boring,’ she said. ‘Everyone will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little hat will make me special.’ She touched the red and black small hat on her head. ‘Yes,’ she said, ‘this is the one I want.’ Mia smiled and agreed that the woman would look special at the wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen’s birthday today, and they were having a family party. Mia was happy to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also excited to meet Jen’s friend. They did not know much about this friend. Her husband Jeff had asked, ‘Tattie? What kind of name is that?’ ‘It’s short for Tatiana,’ Mia said. ‘I think it’s nice.’ Jeff did not like fancy things. He always said Mia was too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she chose the wrong hat. He might have said a trash can lid would look better. ‘You’re too polite,’ he often told Mia. An hour later, Mia closed the shop and went home. Her shop was next to her house. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia had an idea. She turned the barn next to their house into a shop. Jeff was not sure. ‘Do you think people want hats?’ he asked. Mia knew they did. Her friends always said it was hard to find the right hat. She was right. From the first day, Mia’s Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her shop in Little Pelham. They could try on many hats. Mia also sold handbags and jewelry.'

'Lawrence Okoye is from London. He moved to Atlanta, USA. Lawrence is on a new sports journey. He was in the Olympic final for discus. Now, he wants to play American football. Lawrence never played American football before. But he might join a big USA team. In Atlanta, he is learning his new position. Lawrence is 21 years old. It is surprising that he might join a big team. Lawrence is good at surprising people. He was going to study law at Oxford University. But he decided to train for discus. He also played rugby before. In 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world. Lawrence went to Atlanta for discus training. He wanted to get ready for the world championships. He thought about American football before. But he decided to try it in the USA. He read about NFL trials in Atlanta. He applied online. He was not nervous. Lawrence did well in tests and drills. He was the best player. He was happy to hear that. Lawrence knows he needs to work hard. He is waiting to see if he is selected. He is not worried. He did not do well in the Olympic final. But he was happy to be in the final. He can try again. Lawrence does not talk about his Olympic result. NFL players earn a lot of money. Lawrence changed from rugby to discus and now to American football. People ask if he should focus on one sport. Lawrence says he wants to try his dream. If it does not work, he can go back to discus. He thinks carefully about his choices.'

'We were flying east all night. I woke up and saw it was daylight. I looked out the window and saw the land below. It was brown and green. It was mid-September, but there was no snow in Siberia yet. I saw no people, just mountains, streams, and forests. My neighbor woke up and smiled. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a Russian accent. Sergei was from Moscow. He was going to sell safety clothes to miners. His English was not very good, and my Russian was not good either. But with a dictionary, I told him I was going to Magadan in Siberia. I had a one-way ticket because I wanted to go back to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I said I thought there was a road, but not many people used it. "Alone?" he asked. "No, with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I said. Sergei still looked unsure. He said "Holodna" (cold) and pointed outside. I told him I had warm clothes, but I did not say I had little money. My clothes were cheap. I was not sure they would work. My big over-trousers cost £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students. Some were taking notes. The lecturer talked on. I was thinking about a question. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I wrote a note: "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." Al was in front of me. I tapped him and gave him the note. He read it, thought, wrote something, and gave it back. I read it. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I was a geography teacher. The job was hard but good. It was not boring, and I had long holidays for adventures. Twice, I met Al during holidays. After our bike ride in Pakistan, Al wanted more adventures. He decided to cycle around the world. This was his biggest challenge. Sometimes he thought he could not do it. It was hard, but I envied him. He was having a big adventure. He was doing something scary every day, and it made him feel alive.'

'In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots race through tall pylons. The pylons are 15 to 25 meters high. The pilots make sharp turns and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to try it. One hour before the flight, I signed two forms. The first form said I was healthy. The second form said I would empty my pockets. Small things can be dangerous in the flight. I learned to stay focused. 'The horizon is your best friend,' they said. The pilot would tell me where to look. I promised to relax when flying upside down. I had a safety talk. They told me not to touch anything. When we were on the runway, I was nervous. My feet did not touch the pedals. My hands did not touch the switches. I decided not to relax. To stay safe, I had to be calm and focused. I had to tense and relax at the right times. Panicking was bad. The plane started to move. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540. It is one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off and turned right. I felt the air push on me. I looked at the horizon and tensed up. For a moment, I felt very heavy. Then we flew straight. We turned left and dived. My stomach felt strange. We flew close to the ground between two pylons. We went 400 km per hour. We turned right. I was excited but scared. I flew the plane for two minutes. My hand shook. The plane shook too. Then Dario did a barrel roll. It is a full 360-degree turn. 'Are you okay?' he asked. 'Yes,' I said, but I was not sure. Then he did a loop. We flew in a circle. Some people like this. I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, I heard, 'Relax, look up.' I saw fields. The flight was 10 minutes long. It was easy compared to a real race. Dario ate a sandwich after we landed. I did not eat for hours. That night, I dreamed of flying in loops.'

Doug Allan films animals in cold places. If you have seen polar bears in a nature film, he probably filmed them. He likes it when the temperature is -18C. Allan studied marine biology and was a commercial diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned about cold places. His big chance came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. He helped the crew and realized he loved being a wildlife cameraman. He likes travel, adventure, and underwater filming. Now, he is a top cameraman and has worked on many big TV wildlife shows. 
When he started 35 years ago, cameras were simple. It is easier to film today. Before, you had to remember what you filmed. Now, with digital technology, you can see it right away. Film was expensive, so you filmed less. Today, you can film a lot. 
Allan is good at working in cold places. He feels comfortable on sea ice. He says there are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes in these places. Wildlife filming has successes and failures. Once, he went to the Orkneys to film birds but could not find the right ones. 
Recently, he filmed in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. It is a place with polar bears and is very cold, usually -32C in April. The wind is strong, and carrying cameras in the snow is hard. After 23 days, he saw only one mother bear and her cub. On day 24, he saw more bears. He watched a mother bear come out of her den with her cubs. It was a special moment. 
Now, Allan wants to make a film about climate change in the Arctic. He wants to talk to people who live there and see the changes. He thinks he can make a great documentary.

'In 2004, Pen Hadow was the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without help. He swam in very cold water and faced polar bears. Eight months later, he went to the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic for a new trip. This trip is very important. Pen and two friends will walk 1,000 kilometers to the North Pole. They will measure the ice. No one has done this before. The information will help scientists understand global warming. Pen was trained for this. As a child, he was cared for by a woman who worked for a famous explorer. She sent him outside in cold weather with little clothing. His father loved cold adventures, and Pen became very strong. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps with his polar guide business. Mary says Pen is in more danger driving at home than in the Arctic. For fun, Mary once raced Pen in a mountain event. She finished an hour before him. Pen and Mary have two children. Pen finds it hard to leave them. Last time, he told his son to take care of the family, which was too much for him. This time, Pen will not call them much. He is getting ready for the trip. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, a photographer, will join him. A team of six will bring supplies. Pen says being in a team is stressful for him. He is also worried because he is almost 47 and has not trained enough. Pen thinks this trip is important for science. He wants to help people understand what is happening in the Arctic. He says their skills are now very useful.'

I had a year off. What was I going to do? Being an Olympian is special. I had time to write, work on TV, and talk to businesses and schools. These activities were fun, but I wanted something competitive. I wanted to stay fit in case I wanted to try for the Olympics again. So, I joined marathons and triathlons. That was good, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's question: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to my rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. If I joined, I would want to win. Would Ben help me win? No. But being the underdog sounded fun. I called Ben. He was going to do the race and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat. The race was possible. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000. It was a lot of money. I also thought about losing money from not working. Speaking at business events is a good way to earn money. People like to hear about my past, but I wanted a new goal. Doing the race meant I could talk about rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure. Being an athlete was hard, but simple. I trained every day, but I had help from doctors and dieticians. I worried people would think I just wanted to be on TV with Ben. But during our preparations, I stopped worrying. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than rowing. Ben had done tough things before, but he couldn't row well. I was surprised by this, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

'A year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in Finland. I was 26 and wanted a change from busy London. I found a small company run by Anna and her husband, Pasi, in Finnish Lapland. They let me work as a husky dog handler for the winter. From December to February, tourists go on sled rides pulled by huskies. The company started with six dogs and now has more than 100. They also have a second place called the 'wilderness farm' with no running water. I could join them for three months if I was ready for hard work. 'The hours are long, and the work is tough,’ they said. I started packing right away. November 6, London On my flight, I looked at pictures of over 100 huskies. I needed to learn their names, but I was nervous. I looked out of the window instead. November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north was what I hoped for. We drove through dark forests and saw reindeer. I arrived at the farm after dark and was given boots to go outside. 'Do you want to start right away?’ Anna asked. I followed the barking to the dogs. People were getting the dogs ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited. I joined them and got into a sled. We went into the dark with only a light on our heads. November 15, Hetta I quickly learned to be a husky guide. Anna asked if I was useful. I didn’t know. I had never driven a snowmobile or chopped wood. But I had a driving license. I learned the basics of dog-sledding: lean in corners, use the brake to stop, and don’t let go. Feeding the dogs was hard because water freezes. We made a 'soup' of meat and hot water for them. After a week, I was tired but happy. 'I can chop wood and use tools,’ I told my friends. 'In the snow.’'

'On that day, Radcliffe ran very fast and finished the race. The press was surprised by her amazing run. Her time was so good that she could compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Reporters asked her about using emu oil, a natural treatment. Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had told her about it. Radcliffe used it after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says she did not really understand how big her achievement was. She and her team had a motto: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her team. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometres, Radcliffe's agent worried she was running too fast. Hartmann was angry about this but understood why someone might think it was risky. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe thought she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes. She ran the last part in 2 minutes 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run faster.’ The race director, Dave Bedford, said he did not think anyone would beat that time soon. Radcliffe thought she would try again next year, but it did not happen. People wanted to know how she beat the East African runners. Hartmann worked with Radcliffe a lot, helping her with the pain from running so much. He said she was very strong and could handle a lot of pain. Hartmann traveled from Ireland to France to help her. Radcliffe was always ready to train hard. Other athletes were upset because Hartmann spent so much time with her. Radcliffe does not know why no one has beaten her record. She trained very hard but thinks others are more talented. She thought Mary Keitany might beat her record. Radcliffe says she always pushed herself and never relaxed. That marathon was her best race. She never ran as fast again, but she inspired many women to start running long distances.'

'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, started, I did not know if people would like it. At that time, many people were talking about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I thought our show was new and different, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show with history, memories, and science? I watched the first show feeling both happy and scared. I did not need to worry. The show was a success and led to other projects, like a book about my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I wrote more books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was real, with travel and meeting new people. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest book. In it, you travel the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best pasta. These people have spent many years trying to be perfect. Perfection is different for everyone. Choosing which dishes to include in the show was hard. I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. But after a long meeting, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on feelings, memories, and places. I knew the recipes were not 'perfect', but I used my skills and talked to food experts to find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV show let me explore new foods, people, and places. I was excited to learn about memory and nostalgia in food. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had adventures like visiting a tomato factory that used the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that was not good enough to film. I learned new techniques, like hand-milking a cow to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house down to make pizza.'

'We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and stopped in a field. John got out and looked at the engine. He said, ‘I don’t know what I’m doing,’ and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, ‘We can’t stay here forever,’ she said. The field was big, with grass and flowers. ‘No, we can’t stay here forever,’ I said. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay on the grass. ‘Tell us a story,’ she said. Bea lay next to her. I told them about two birds I heard in London. They talked about food, other birds, and the weather. Bea said, ‘That’s silly, no one understands birds.’ I said, ‘I do.’ But I wasn’t sure. ‘Mum…?’ But she was asleep. John came back with three Moroccan boys. They helped push the van to a hotel. Bea stayed in the van. The boys waved and smiled at her. We went into a café near the road. ‘It’s a hotel,’ John said. ‘It might be expensive.’ ‘We’ll just have tea,’ Mum said. The tea was very sweet.
