Mum said, ‘It’s like syrup.’ We stayed all day while John looked at the engine. ‘It’s a miracle it got us this far,’ he said. Mum made a bed for us outside. It was nice to sleep on the ground. ‘I’ll have to tow us to Marrakech,’ John said. Later, we were in a truck with our van behind us. John drove the van. Bea sat in the front with the driver. I thought about how we’d get home. Maybe we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.'

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel. She talked to two other pianists. One was a man from Tokyo, and the other was a woman from Europe. Lucy didn't hear the woman's name clearly. They were both older than Lucy, about ten years older. They spoke English well and talked about the music they played and their travels.
Lucy said, "I think I'm going to Tanglewood this summer." It sounded impressive. But Lucy didn't really want to go. She didn't want to do many of the things she did, like concerts and competitions. These events made her miss a lot of school. She wasn't in school anymore and studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco.
Lucy didn't even want to come to the Prague Festival. Only fifteen pianists her age were chosen from around the world. Lucy's dad bought her a necklace to celebrate, and her teacher, Grace Chang, took her to dinner to plan her music. Lucy's mom had sent in the application for her. Lucy thought her mom didn't want her to say no.
The man from Tokyo asked Lucy, "How old are you?" She said, "Fifteen." He looked at the woman, who said, "Wow." Lucy didn't want to brag. She just wanted to fit in.
The woman left, and the man asked Lucy if she had been to Japan. Lucy said she went once when she was eight. Then Lucy's grandfather came and took her to meet other people at the party. He said, "Everyone is the competition."
After the party, in the elevator, her grandfather said, "You did well, Lucy. I'm proud of you. People know who you are." Lucy liked being important, even if some people were jealous. At school, her friends didn't care about her music skills. But at the festival, she felt she mattered.

"‘You spend too much time online. You need to go outside,’ said Dad. I wanted to know what experts say about this. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends and are learning important skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social media is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers live in it, not just use it like adults. It’s not good or bad; it depends on how you use it. Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says social media is like a virtual youth club. It helps teenagers find out who they are and learn to get along with others. Professor Keith Davidson, a psychologist, says social media can help teenagers understand themselves. They can share their favorite music or sports and see different opinions. People who use social media a lot are not as self-centered as those who don’t. Social media can be easier for shy people because it’s less scary than talking face-to-face. Professor Andrew Phillips studies young people using social media. He says it helps quiet people with special interests find others like them. Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online and create content are using social media well. They make videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers learn and share. This can help them get jobs in the future. Businesses use social media to sell and need people who understand it. Teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they work. Matthews agrees that working with others online is an important skill for jobs today."

'When most people think of a family vacation, they don't usually think of a long trip through nine states in the US and a part of Canada. But my parents wanted a different kind of vacation this year. My dad planned a big family trip. He said, "Not enough people do this anymore." My twin brother and I were not so sure about it. In June, we packed our car with bags and clothes. We had little space left in the car, but we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." We left our home and drove west through Oklahoma. We had some adventures, like a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right-of-way on the road! The next day, we woke up early and drove again. We saw deserts and mountains. We visited the Great Sand Dunes and Pagosa Springs in Colorado. We learned that some roads are only for Jeeps. We saw many wind farms and went to Yellowstone National Park. We saw bears near the road. We stayed in an old hotel with no internet or phone service, but the views were amazing. After a rainstorm in Canada, we drove back home. My parents were right. We didn't need to go far to see something special. It was nice to be home, and I didn't fight with my brother during the trip! We took many photos of our journey. I will remember the unplanned and fun moments.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her sister Amy were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school and live at the college. She had a nice room with a kitchen and study area. Jeff and Dahlia would still watch over Amy.
Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She remembered her grandmother from holidays but never knew her grandfather. Rose's parents were not happy about her staying with Daisy, but Daisy wanted to know her granddaughter again. Rose didn’t know why her parents didn’t like Daisy, but she had happy memories of her. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy liked to meet people and go to events. Rose thought this was funny. Daisy was not like a typical old lady.
Before moving, Rose talked with her mom. Rose was mature and knew about healthy living. She wanted some independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends, and go out without asking all the time. Daisy understood. Rose’s mom gave her a new phone for emergencies. They agreed to trust each other. Rose would act mature, and Daisy would not be too strict. If there were problems, they would talk about it.
Rose was not a wild child. Her school reports were good. In five weeks, Rose would start a new school and make new friends. It was her fourth school in five years. She felt ready for it. This was her last move, and she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new start in her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to think she might write a book. Charlotte thought writing a book was a big challenge. When she was 13, she decided to try. Now, her book is about to be published. She told her old teacher, who was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait if she was good at it.
Charlotte is 15 years old now, and her book is a big success. It has a strong story and lots of action. It doesn’t seem like a teenager wrote it. Charlotte is confident and smart. She knows she is young and doesn’t have all the answers. She wanted to ask big questions in her book, like about taking responsibility.
Charlotte thinks many books for teenagers show them in three ways: as outsiders, as naïve, or as awkward. She didn’t like this. She wanted to write about teenagers who are okay as they are. She believes teenagers can know who they are, even if they are young.
Charlotte likes reading fantasy books, but they almost stopped her from writing. She thought she had to write about deep things to be good. She learned from a book called How Not to Write a Novel that if readers can guess what happens next, the story loses suspense.
Charlotte’s parents are journalists, and this helped her get her book read. Her father knew someone in publishing. She knows she was lucky, but she also believes writers succeed because of their talent.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our teacher, as we looked at the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one man, David, who knew a bit about ski-jumping, went first. He skied fast and jumped. His arms were in the air. We saw something was wrong. We watched. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed is tricky.’ Maybe I was not good at this freestyle skiing. On other ski holidays, I liked practising turns in the snow. I was not one of those teenagers who did tricks on ramps in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I did not know how to do it. My parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing school in the US. It had a big indoor place with trampolines and ski jumps with fake snow. Students jumped and landed in foam cubes. After practising inside, students went outside to try for real. ‘You will get better!’ the school said. ‘Before places like this, new ski jumpers just went down the slopes and hoped for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the flat part, you will be in trouble.’ The ‘flat part’ is the section before the slope goes down again. Land in the right place and you keep moving. Land on the flat and you stop, which hurts. So, you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body go fast to the jump. My legs slowed down, so I landed on the flat part. I did not fall, but I felt tired. ‘You need to control the jump,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I would not like being inside, but bouncing was fun. Some moves were like ski-jumping, others helped us know what our body was doing in the air. Gareth talked to us. My ‘air sense’ needed work. Every time I tried, I only knew the moment before jumping, then I was in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. I had more problems before I landed right. Gareth was happy, and I was proud. But it did not last. On the last run, I did not slow down, jumped, and landed in the right place. Then I saw my skis going down the slope without me."

'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at a fun park. Your hands are sweaty, and you hold on tight. The ride stops, and you take a deep breath. Then, the rollercoaster goes up slowly. It pauses. Suddenly, it drops fast, and you feel your stomach in the air. You go forward, left, and upside down. You scream because you are scared. But you chose to be here, like many people who visit theme parks every year. 
Theme parks are big business. They have exciting rides to make people happy. Many people work to make these rides, like engineers and designers. They want to make rides fun and safe. Making a rollercoaster is hard. It needs to be fun and a little scary, but not dangerous. 
A long time ago, a man named John Miller made many rollercoaster ideas. Today, people still use his ideas. I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer', said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts said it is about making people feel excited but safe. 
Rollercoaster teams create stories, like space adventures or jungle chases, to make rides more fun. Professor Walker said that experience and trying new things help make good rides. Jeff Hornick, a theme park director, said designers need to love thrills to understand what people want. 
I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoasters. Walker said it can add to the ride, but the real rollercoaster experience is still the most important part. He thinks this will stay true for many years.'

'Miranda Ellington is 25 years old. She is a choreographer and has made dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. Miranda likes to dance because it reminds her of how it feels to be a dancer. She says it can be hard and stressful. As a choreographer, she teaches young students. She likes working with them because they are open to new ideas and want to succeed. They listen to feedback, even if it is not always nice. When Miranda works with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps and the music. Sometimes she does not like the music, but she still tries to make a good dance. She cannot change the music because it is already chosen. Miranda likes to meet new people and work in different places. She changes how she works each time. She watched a documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. She thinks it shows the real life of dancers. Miranda believes a great dance show has good music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Everything must work well together. She does not want to be known for just one type of dance. She wants to try many things.'

'A friend asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I said you can see great things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to see? This talk gave me the idea for my fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I put three wheels and some cables on it and used old seatbelts to pull it. I put my bags on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends helped me pull the sofa and cheered me on. I have walked a lot in the past, but this was new. It was the longest walk I have done, and it was on main roads. I could stop at a café and relax on the sofa with a coffee. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, I’m not training for a marathon”. When someone at work asks about my weekend, I like to say how I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England, not talk about the latest TV show. You can see the film on my website.'

'I read about swimming trips in the sea around small Greek islands. I was excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I traveled with before, was busy. So, I decided to try a group holiday. At the Greek port, the man was curious when I asked for one ferry ticket. The islands are popular with families. I told him I would join ten others to swim around the islands. He was still puzzled, but he smiled and showed me on board. Our group sent emails before we started, but we did not have much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides said a support boat would be with us, and showed us how to talk to it. We did a short swim to make speed groups. Then, it was time for our first 1.5 km swim. I was nervous. I trained in my local pool and did some river swimming, but never in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger. I was at the back of the slow group. I watched faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first swim, and I was happy when I did it alone. The next days were the same: jumping in, swimming at a good speed, and stopping to look at the scenery. The swims got longer, and I got faster and happier. We did not need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come again next year.'

'Being a flight attendant is not easy. But since I started, I have traveled a lot, from the US to Australia. I work with great people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. This makes it a good job for a young person like me! As a child, I went to a school in another country, away from my family. I flew alone when school started and ended. I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers. Some said yes. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and find something new. At the interview, there were many young people, and many got the job. They were often very qualified like me and wanted a new career. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my strengths and past work experience, not just that I loved to travel. I got the job! I recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and we say, ‘no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished.’ It’s like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home. If I have difficult passengers, which is not often, I know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!'

'At the summer camp where I work, I like seeing the children do things they thought they couldn't do. Most children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel scared, but after we help them, they try and reach the top. This makes them feel happy. Some children miss home at the start of the week. It's not the very young ones who miss home the most – it's the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we say they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's too late now, do it tomorrow. Most children feel okay in a few days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time. Sometimes, it's not the children who feel lonely. We have parents who call a lot, asking how their child is doing, which is not needed. Often their child is busy, playing games or doing something else, so we tell the parents to call back later. We often see a certain type of child coming, usually wearing new, expensive clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something better for camp, but soon they understand why.'

'Rock the Planet is a musical show. The actors must be good musicians. It started in London last year. Before that, it was in the USA for five years. It won ‘Best Musical’ four times there! In the UK, young actors can do fewer shows each week than in the USA. So, they needed more actors in London. The director found many talented actors in the UK. They won their first ‘Best Musical’ award in London. The London theatre is bigger than the one in the USA. It is full every night. People want to hear the songs from America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘I get paid to play a beautiful Gibson guitar.’ Jamie said the young actors are busy. They have school lessons at the theatre. He misses his old school friends. His class came to see the show. The theatre has special ticket prices for schools. His class loved the show. Jamie’s parents come when they can, but it is expensive. I told Jamie I play guitar too. He gave me a guitar to play with him and the other actors. We played a song called Days. Jamie helped me learn it. I was happy when I played it right. Jamie is very good at playing. I wished I could play like him. The young actors were already musicians. Some play many instruments. But they never played in a band before. They found it easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural. They forgot to smile at first! The show will be in London for another year. It is very good to see.'
